description:
pseudo- +â€Ž linguistic.
In use in sense (1.) from the early 20th century.

entries.meaning: pertaining to pseudo-linguistics. Deprecating of scholarship thought to purport to be linguistic but falling short of the necessary standards
examples: representatives of previous pseudolinguistic science, the philologists (The Rice institute pamphlets, Volume 2 (1915), p. 172)

entries.meaning: quasilinguistic. Having some qualities similar to language, but not quite amounting to language in the narrow sense.
